newsitem.title: UK: Dutch PM to talk Europe with Britain's Blair.
newsitem.headline: Dutch PM to talk Europe with Britain's Blair.

text.p: Dutch Prime Minister Wim Kok will be hoping the new British government's honeymoon with the European Union is still thriving when he arrives on Friday for talks on a crucial EU summit next month.
Kok and Prime Minister Tony Blair will focus on the mid-June meeting of the Inter-Governmental Committee (IGC), where the 15 EU leaders will vote on a treaty on further European integration.

The Netherlands, which holds the revolving EU presidency until the end of June, has taken a cautiously optimistic line on the new British government which is trying hard to be seen as more cooperative than the defeated Conservatives.
Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van Mierlo adopted an optimistic tone, saying Britain's European partners hoped to benefit from the feeling that new roads were opening up.
"Perhaps one of these roads leads a bit more directly to Europe," he said, adding that he was not expecting any quick or radical changes.

Although Britain has made clear the days of antagonism are over, the truth remains that the ruling Labour Party's position on a number of crucial issues hardly differs from those adopted by the Conservatives, who were soundly defeated in the polls a week ago after 18 years of unbroken rule.

Labour is adopting a wait-and-see policy on whether to sign up to a single European currency and is pressing for an end to a damaging EU ban on British beef exports imposed last year amid a scare over mad cow disease.
The Conservatives had threatened to torpedo the IGC summit unless the EU agreed to change its fisheries policy but Labour has ruled out any suggestion of sabotage.
This new-style approach to European affairs was underlined when Foreign Secretary Robin Cook paid a flying visit to Paris and Bonn on Wednesday to say Britain wanted to be at the heaart of Europe.

The Bonn-based General Anzeiger greeted the trip but said there was no sign Blair would drop his opposition to majority decision-making and give up the principle of unanimity on key issues such as foreign and justice policy.
"It is much too early to talk about a new European spring," the paper concluded.
Kok and Blair are both reformers who moved their parties toward the centre of the political spectrum by rejecting socialist dogma.
But it remains to be seen whether the new British premier shares his Dutch counterpart's enthusiasm for European integration.
